answers.explanation:
AS-OCT in microcystic edema shows hypo-reflective subepithelial spaces representing intraepithelial bullae. The white arrow highlights a hypo-reflective subepithelial fluid pocket beneath the epithelium. 

Microcystic bullae are a recognized complication of eye surgeries such as cataract surgery or laser-assisted in situ keratoplasty (LASIK). Persistent microcystic changes may suggest underlying corneal decompensation or retained surgical material (1).

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of microcystic edema in this patient?

answers.explanation: Corneal microcystic edema after eye surgeries such as DMEK or cataract surgery is typically linked to endothelial cell trauma, leading to stromal and epithelial fluid accumulation (2). The most accepted mechanism is that surgical trauma impairs endothelial barrier function, which typically keeps the cornea dehydrated for a clear view. This results in excessive corneal edema, which manifests as microcystic changes or bullae in the epithelial layer.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for symptomatic microcystic corneal edema?

answers.answerText: C. Hypertonic saline drops and/or bandage contact lens
answers.explanation: Hypertonic saline is the first-line therapy for mild or transient symptomatic corneal edema. It creates a hypertonic tear film to draw fluid out of the cornea when used for at least 3 months (3).

### ​Learning Objectives

1. Understand the imaging features of microcystic corneal edema, which include hypo-reflective subepithelial cysts on AS-OCT.

2. Recognize that transient microcystic corneal edema may occur with surgical trauma.

3. Recognize that topical hypertonic saline drops are used for reducing transient microcystic corneal edema.
